testcase.name: myTest

error.message: Response body doesn't match expectation. Expected: a string containing "05/26/15" Actual: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of diarrhea; a red, scaly rash; and mild unsteady gait. His mother says that his diet is not deficient in protein or any other caloric foods or nutrients. She says that his sister has a similar condition. Urinalysis shows large amounts of free amino acids. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition? Alkaptonuria Carcinoid tumor Cystinuria Hartnup disease HomocystinuriaThe correct answer is D. This child has Hartnup disease, an autosomal recessive condition resulting from defective amino acid transporters in intestinal and renal epithelial cells. Despite normal dietary intake, these patients present with poor absorption of dietary amino acids and excess amino acid secretion in urine. Specifically, in Hartnup disease, there is impaired transport of neutral amino acids, including tryptophan, which is the precursor for niacin (requires B6 cofactor). This condition clinically resembles pellagra ("diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis") and may be misdiagnosed as this nutritional (niacin) deficiency. Niacin supplementation may be helpful in controlling the symptoms. Alkaptonuria (choice A) is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by urine that turns black on standing and, in later life, a debilitating arthritis. Cartilage also accumulates the dark brown/black pigmentation (ochronosis). Other features include pigmented sclera and kidney stones. Alkaptonuria results from deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase, an important enzyme in the tyrosine degradation pathway. Dysfunction results in accumulation of homogentisic acid. Carcinoid syndrome (choice B) can also produce niacin deficiency. The syndrome occurs when serotonin-producing gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors metastasize to the liver. By spreading to the liver, the secreted serotonin can bypass hepatic metabolism, causing diarrhea, flushing, heart murmurs, and wheezing. Importantly, production of serotonin by the tumor requires tryptophan precursor, make it unavailable for niacin production. Niacin deficiency and symptoms of pellagra, including diarrhea, photosensitive dermatitis, and dementia, then ensue. The age of our patient and urinalysis findings make carcinoid tumor an unlikely diagnosis. Cystinuria (choice C) is an autosomal recessive defect in renal epithelial transport of cysteine and the basic amino acids lysine, arginine, and ornithine. Absorption of these amino acids normally occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule. Defective absorption means cysteine accumulates in renal tubules and forms cystine (two cysteine molecules attached by disulfide bond), which can precipitate as cystine kidney stones. This process relies on an acidic tubular environment, thus alkalization of the urine (acetazolamide) can treat this issue. The other amino acids listed are much more soluble than cystine and do not cause nephrolithiasis. Homocystinuria (choice E) is an autosomal recessive deficiency of various enzymes in the cysteine synthesis pathway. Affected enzymes include cystathionine synthase and homocysteine methyltransferase. The net result is excess serum homocysteine (and decreased cysteine), which disrupts connective tissue, blood vessels, and the coagulation cascade. Patient findings include mental retardation, Marfanoid habitus, osteoporosis, hypercoagulability (deep vein thrombosis, etc.), and increased risk for cardiovascular disease. As a caveat, on the USMLE, be careful to distinguish between Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria, since both present with similar connective tissue findings. Symptoms inconsistent with Marfan syndrome include mental retardation, hypercoagulability, limited joint mobility, downward lens subluxation (Marfan is upwards), and seizures. There are also no amino acid abnormalities in Marfan syndrome. Updated on 05/26/2015MedEssentials (4th Ed.): pp. 48First Aid (2015): pp. 531.3First Aid (2014): pp. 527.2First Aid (2013): pp. 109.4Hartnup disease resembles pellagra ("diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis") and may be misdiagnosed as nutritional deficiency of niacin. Hartnup disease is due to a defect in the epithelial transport of neutral amino acids, including tryptophan, which is a precursor for niacin production. The defective amino acid transport leads to poor absorption of dietary amino acids and excess amino acid secretion in the urine.

error.message: Expected: an XML document with XPath /question/explanation/para[5]/emphasis Actual: A researcher is studying the developmental origins of the arteries that supply blood to the brain. The investigation involves injecting contrast media into the hearts of fetal pigs and studying the arteries that develop in the pharyngeal arches, because blood vessels that develop bilaterally in several of these structures supply the circle of Willis. Which of the following pairs of pharyngeal arches gives rise to arteries that contribute to the blood vessels in the circle of Willis? Pharyngeal arches 1 and 2Pharyngeal arches 2 and 3Pharyngeal arches 3 and 4Pharyngeal arches 4 and 5Pharyngeal arches 4 and 6The correct answer is C. Arch 3 gives rise to the internal carotid artery bilaterally, and arch 4 gives rise to the arch of the aorta and the right subclavian artery. The internal carotid arteries branch into the middle and anterior cerebral arteries that form the anterior circulation. The subclavian arteries give rise to the vertebral arteries that join to form the vertebrobasilar or posterior circulation. The anterior and posterior circulations are linked by the posterior communicating arteries to form the circle of Willis.Pharyngeal arches 1 (choice A) and 2 (choices A and B) give rise to the maxillary artery and the stapedial artery, respectively.Arch 5 (choice D) degenerates early in fetal development, and arch 6 (choice E) gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and to the ductus arteriosus.Reviewed on 05/25/15MedEssentials (4th Ed.): pp. 428First Aid (2015): pp. 565.1First Aid (2014): pp. 559.1First Aid (2013): pp. 510.1Pharyngeal arch 3 gives rise to the internal carotid arteries, which form the anterior circulation (middle and anterior cerebral arteries) of the circle of Willis. Pharyngeal arch 4 gives rise to the subclavian arteries, which form the posterior circulation (vertebral arteries) of the circle of Willis.

testcase.name: myTest

error.message: Expected: an XML document with XPath /question/explanation/para[5]/emphasis Actual: The graph shows spirographic tracings of forced expirations from two different individuals. Trace X was obtained from an individual with healthy lungs. Trace Y was most likely obtained from an individual with which of the following conditions? Asthma Bronchospasm Emphysema Interstitial fibrosis Old age The correct answer is D. A forced expiration is the simplest test of lung function. The individual breathes in as much air as the lungs can hold and then expels the air as rapidly and as far as possible. The forced vital capacity (FVC) is the vital capacity measured with a forced expiration (FVC = 3 L for patient Y). The forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) is the amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs during the first second of a forced expiration (FEV1 = 2.7 L for patient Y). The FEV1/FVC ratio has diagnostic value for differentiating between normal, obstructive, and restrictive patterns of a forced expiration. The FEV1/FVC ratio for the healthy individual (patient X) is 4 L/5 L = 80%, and the FEV1/FVC ratio for patient Y is 2.7/3.0 = 90%. FEV1/FVC ratio is a function of airway resistance. Increases in airway resistance associated with asthma (choice A), bronchospasm (choice B), emphysema (choice C), and old age (choice E) tend to decrease the FEV1/FVC ratio below its typical normal value of 80%. FEV1/FVC ratio is often increased with interstitial fibrosis because of increased radial traction of the airways (i.e., the airways are held open to a greater extent at any given lung volume, reducing their resistance to airflow). The increase in elastic recoil also makes it difficult to breathe deeply, which decreases FVC. This combination of decreased FVC with normal or slightly increased FEV1/FVC ratio is characteristic of fibrotic lung disease. Reviewed on 05/28/15MedEssentials (4th Ed.): pp. 281First Aid (2015): pp. 611.2First Aid (2014): pp. 607.2First Aid (2013): pp. 556.2Pathoma (2014): pp. 92.2Pathoma (2013): pp. 92.2Increased FEV1/FVC suggests fibrotic lung disease. Decreased FEV1/FVC can be seen in asthma, bronchospasm, emphysema, and old age.

testcase.name: myTest

error.message: Expected: an XML document with XPath /question/explanation/para[5]/emphasis Actual: The graph shows the relationship between NaCl delivery to the macula densa and resistance in the afferent arteriole. Based on the data, which of the following diuretics will most likely result in afferent arteriole vasoconstriction? AcetazolamideAmilorideFurosemideHydrochlorothiazideSpironolactoneThe correct answer is A. Acetazolamide is the only diuretic that acts primarily upstream of the macula densa without decreasing NaCl transport into macula densa cells. As a result of blocking carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, acetazolamide causes an osmotic diuresis that increases the delivery of NaCl to the macula densa. The macula densa detects the transport of sodium chloride in the tubular cell, and is the signal for tubuloglomerular feedback, the control of the afferent arteriole by macula densa detection of NaCl. Since only the sodium chloride that enters the macula densa cell will be detected, actetazolamide will increase the signal that causes afferent constriction. If the tubular load of sodium increases and early distal tubule transport mechanisms are intact, then the increased tubular load of sodium will decrease renin secretion (which will mainly dilate the efferent arteriole, to reduce GFR) and, at the same time, constrict the afferent arteriole through tubuloglomerula feedback. This happens with acetazolamide treatment. Through tubuloglomerular feedback, the afferent arteriole constricts, increasing the resistance. All of the other diuretics act at the macula densa or downstream. Therefore, either they would not increase delivery of NaCl or would reduce NaCl transport there, even though NaCl tubular load would be increased. Increased NaCl transport is the most commonly described mechanism for the constriction of afferent arterioles with increased tubular load of sodium.Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, such as acetazolamide, inhibit both the membrane-bound and cytoplasmic forms of carbonic anhydrase. This results in a decrease of NaHCO3 reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase is also associated with a rapid increase in urinary HCO3- excretion, which results in a urinary pH of approximately 8 and development of a metabolic acidosis.Amiloride (choice B) blocks the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the collecting duct and is a K+ -sparing diuretic.Furosemide (choice C), a loop diuretic, inhibits the NKCC triple transporter in the thick ascending limb. This transporter is also present in macula densa cells. With furosemide, the tubular load of NaCl at the macula densa increases, but as a result of furosemidersquos effect on macula densa transport, the increased tubular load of sodium is not detected; in fact, the macula densa responds to the decreased transport as if there were a reduction of tubular sodium. Because the transport of sodium within the distal tubular cell is decreased by the drug, it responds as if tubular load of sodium is decreased; this provokes increased secretion of renin, which constricts the efferent arteriole and increases GFR. Hydrochlorothiazide (choice D) inhibits the sodium chloride cotransporter in the distal tubule, and has the same effect as furosemide on the ability to detect tubular load of sodium. In fact, both loop and thiazide diuretics can provoke sufficient increase in plasma renin activity and angiotensin II to elicit increased total peripheral resistance; this has been reported to transiently reduce the antihypertensive benefit of these drugs. Spironolactone (choice E) is a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist in the collecting duct and is considered a K+-sparing diuretic; therefore, it does not have a major effect of NaCl transport in the macula densa.Reviewed on 05/26/15MedEssentials (4th Ed.): pp. 326, 513First Aid (2015): pp. 553.2First Aid (2014): pp. 547.2First Aid (2013): pp. 500.2Acetazolamide causes osmotic diuresis as it blocks carbonic anhydrase.This diuresis leads to increased delivery of sodium to the macula densa.The increase in Na+ through tubuloglomerular feedback constricts the afferent arterioles.

testcase.name: myTest

error.message: Expected: an XML document with XPath /question/explanation/para[5]/emphasis Actual: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a deep puncture wound to her right hand. A shard of glass is removed from the wound, and the wound is cleaned and dressed. The patient is taking medication that decreases chemotaxis of white blood cells via a novel mechanism. A side effect of the drug is poor wound healing and increased infection risk. The drug most likely blocks which of the following molecules? C3bC5aIgMIL-2LysozymeThe correct answer is B. In active inflammation, the complement system is activated and C5a is produced. C5a is a strong chemoattractant to neutrophils and other phagocytic cells. Other chemotactic factors for neutrophils include IL-8, fibrinopeptides, leukotriene B4, and formyl methionyl peptides from bacteria. Blocking C5a would significantly reduce neutrophil chemotaxis into the wound of the patient in the question stem. As with other drugs that decrease the immune response, poor wound healing and increased risk for infection would result. As an example, eculizumab is one such anti-C5a agent. One major side effect of this drug is, in fact, increased infection risk.C3b (choice A) is an opsonin. When an organism is coated with C3b, it is more easily phagocytized. C3b is formed via the classical and alternative complement pathways, but it is not chemotactic for neutrophils. IgM (choice C) is the first immunoglobulin produced in the primary immune response. It is not chemotactic for neutrophils. IL-2 (choice D) is a powerful interleukin that stimulates proliferation of TH cells, natural killer cells, and CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes, but it is not chemotactic for neutrophils. Lysozyme (choice E) is a material present in tears, mucus, vaginal secretions, and other body fluids. It is active against the peptidoglycan of bacterial cell walls, splitting the backbone structure of the peptidoglycan (N-acetylglucosamine and N-acetyl muramic acid polymers). It is not chemotactic for neutrophils. Updated on 05/24/15MedEssentials (4th Ed.): pp. 98, 99First Aid (2015): pp. 206.1First Aid (2014): pp. 204.1First Aid (2013): pp. 199.1Pathoma (2014): pp. 11.3Pathoma (2013): pp. 11.3C5a is a neutrophil chemoattractant causing the accumulation of white blood cells at the site of complement activation. Other chemotactic factors for neutrophils include interleukin-8, fibrinopeptides, leukotriene B4, and formyl methionyl peptides from bacteria.
